title: Theory for missing not at random non-response correction
text: document reveals theory needed understand methodology behind correction missing random type non-responses survey samples. covers methods : Generalized calibration Generalized calibration variables calibration response model Generalized method moments (also known GMM) Empirical likelihood estimation Non-parametric methods Exponential tilting Latent approach Knowledge included particular paper allows one understand correction techniques treated one supplementary resource R programming language package called MNAR.

what: Interpretation of Missing Not at Random
title: Theory for missing not at random non-response correction
text: statistical surveys, missing data plays important role family non-random errors. presence affects process estimating unknown global values population biasing given estimators reducing precision. reason behavior lies characteristics differences respondentsâ€”participants answered every questionâ€”participants manage provide answers every question (item non-response) answer (unit non-response), called non-respondents. happens bunch methods deal non-responses. However, main idea behind construction allows us categorize â€”split weighting methods imputation methods. cases, one able determine groups methods shall used. imputation methods used dealing item non-responseâ€”questions lack answers corrected , e.g., replenishing missing data. weighting methods shall used dealing unit non-responses order correct, using set auxiliary variables, weights respondents non-respondents sample known population totals reproduced. choice mentioned auxiliary variables matters strictly tied estimation process, thus arises biggest problem category methods. One might use combination kinds methods eliminate negative impact non-responses. Investigation described methodology starts explanation assumptions, settings, notation behind sampling, responding, estimation. Starting basic notation, let UU denote population size NN probability sample ss length nn, sâŠ†Us \subseteq U, nâ‰¤Nn \leq N. According sampling design, let Ï€k\pi_k denote first-order inclusion probability kk-th element population UU sample ss. Thus, given sampling design, dk=1Ï€kd_k = \frac{1}{\pi_k} denotes initial weight kk-th element. main goal, dealing survey data, estimate total population UU, written Y=âˆ‘k=1Nyk,\begin{equation}\label{eq:Pop. total} Y = \sum_{k=1}^{N}{y_k}, \end{equation} yky_k value target variable YY kk-th element, k=1,...,Nk = 1,...,N. Natural usual choice consider Horvitz-Thompson estimator form: YÌ‚HT=âˆ‘kâˆˆsdkyk.\begin{equation}\label{eq:HT estimator} \hat{Y}_{\text{HT}} = \sum_{k \s}{d_k y_k}. \end{equation} design, YÌ‚HT\hat{Y}_{\text{HT}} unbiased estimator. happens non-respondents sample, summation done subset rr respondents, râŠ†sr \subseteq s.

what: Case when dimensions of calibration and response-model variables coincide
title: Theory for missing not at random non-response correction
text: Let ğ±=(x1,x2,...,xp)T\boldsymbol{x}= (x_1, x_2, ..., x_p)^{\text{T}} denote benchmark vector chosen auxiliary variables ğ±k=(x1k,x2k,...,xpk)T\boldsymbol{x}_{k} = (x_{1_k}, x_{2_k}, ..., x_{p_k})^{\text{T}} vector auxiliary variables kk-th element sample ss. Settings state ğ—\boldsymbol{X}, vector global auxiliary variablesâ€™ values known, .e. ğ—=(âˆ‘k=1Nx1k,âˆ‘k=1Nx2k,...,âˆ‘k=1Nxpk)T=âˆ‘kâˆˆUğ±k.\begin{equation}\label{eq:Aux. Total}     \boldsymbol{X}= \left(\sum_{k=1}^{N}{x_{1_k}}, \sum_{k=1}^{N}{x_{2_k}}, ..., \sum_{k=1}^{N}{x_{p_k}}\right)^{\text{T}} = \sum_{k \U}{\boldsymbol{x}_k}.  \end{equation} auxiliary values total known, one might use xikx_{i_{k}} instead yky_kâ€™s (), .e.Â XÌ‚HTi=âˆ‘k=1Nxik,=1,...,p.\hat{X}^{}_{\text{HT}} = \sum_{k=1}^{N}{x_{i_k}}, \; = 1, ..., p. However, using ğ±k\boldsymbol{x}_k instead yky_k always work process estimation ğ—\boldsymbol{X}. One needs perform slightly different weights dkd_kâ€™s. weights, denoted wkw_kâ€™s solutions optimization problem form argminwkâˆ‘kâˆˆrGk(wk,dk),\begin{equation}\label{eq: optimization w_k}     \operatorname{argmin}_{w_k}{\sum_{k\r}G_k\left(w_k,d_k\right)}, \end{equation} GkG_k strictly convex, differentiable function, Gk(dk,dk)=0G_k(d_k,d_k) = 0 Gk(1)=Gâ€²k(1)=0G_k(1) = G'_k(1) = 0. Also, exists additional condition satisfied, namely: âˆ‘kâˆˆrwkğ±k=âˆ‘kâˆˆUğ±k.\begin{equation}\label{eq: calib eq}     \sum_{k\r}{w_k\boldsymbol{x}_k} = \sum_{k\U}{\boldsymbol{x}_k}. \end{equation} Equation () also called . Using Lagrange multipliers method, shown Deville SÃ¤rndal (1992), vector calibration weights might written : wk=dkFk(ğ›ŒTğ³k)\begin{equation}\label{eq: w_k minimizers form}     w_k = d_k F_k (\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{\text{T}}\boldsymbol{z}_k) \end{equation} ğ³k\boldsymbol{z}_k vector instrumental variables, coinciding, sense dimensions ğ±k\boldsymbol{x}_k. Later paper, consider situation ğ³k\boldsymbol{z}_k got higher dimension ğ±k\boldsymbol{x}_k. FkF_k inverse Gkâ€²(wk,dk)G_k'(w_k, d_k), defined : Gkâ€²(wk,dk)=âˆ‚Gk(wk,dk)âˆ‚wk.\begin{equation}\label{eq: partial derivative G_k}     G_k'(w_k, d_k) = \frac{\partial{G_k(w_k, d_k)}}{\partial w_k}. \end{equation} various ideas choose function GkG_k common case consider GkG_k form: Gk(wk,dk)=(wkâˆ’dk)22dk\begin{equation}\label{eq: G_k example}     G_k(w_k,d_k) = \frac{\left(w_k - d_k\right)^2}{2d_k} \end{equation} choice, solution wkw_k problem stated () expressed Estevao SÃ¤rndal (n.d.) : wk=dk(1+ğ³kTğ›Œ),\begin{equation}\label{eq:G_k optimizers} w_k = d_k(1 + \boldsymbol{z}_k^{\text{T}}\boldsymbol{\lambda}), \end{equation} ğ \boldsymbol{g} defined follows: ğ =(âˆ‘kâˆˆrdkğ±kğ³kT)âˆ’1Ã—(ğ—âˆ’âˆ‘kâˆˆrdkğ±k).\begin{equation}\label{eq: g vector}     \boldsymbol{g}= \left(\sum_{k \r}{d_k\boldsymbol{x}_k\boldsymbol{z}_k^{\text{T}}}\right)^{-1} \times \left(\boldsymbol{X}- \sum_{k\r}{d_k \boldsymbol{x}_k}\right). \end{equation} Using obtained wkw_k, known linear weights, new, called â€œcalibration-weightedâ€ estimator target variable total () form: YÌ‚cal=âˆ‘kâˆˆrwkyk,\begin{equation}\label{eq: calibration-weighted estimator}     \hat{Y}_{\text{cal}} = \sum_{k \r}{w_k y_k}, \end{equation} can rendered : YÌ‚cal=âˆ‘kâˆˆrdkyk+(ğ—âˆ’âˆ‘kâˆˆrdkğ±k)ğ›,\begin{equation}\label{eq: rendered calibration-weighted estimator}     \hat{Y}_{\text{cal}} = \sum_{k \r }{d_k y_k} + \left(\boldsymbol{X}- \sum_{k\r}{d_k \boldsymbol{x}_k}\right)\boldsymbol{b}, \end{equation} ğ›=(âˆ‘kâˆˆrdkğ³kğ±kT)âˆ’1Ã—âˆ‘kâˆˆrdkğ³kyk.\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{b}= \left(\sum_{k \r}{d_k\boldsymbol{z}_k\boldsymbol{x}_k^{\text{T}}}\right)^{-1} \times \sum_{k \r}{d_k\boldsymbol{z}_k y_k}. \end{equation*} Notice, YÌ‚cal\hat{Y}_{cal} longer unbiased design. However might consistent, described Isaki Fuller (1982). one formulate prediction model case? Letâ€™s denote two indicator random variables: Ij=1jâˆˆURj=1kâˆˆr.\begin{equation*} \displaystyle I_j = 1{j \U} \;\;\; R_j = 1{k\r}. \end{equation*}Kott Chang (2010) proposed double-protection justiï¬cation set equations: {yk=ğ±kTğ›ƒğ±+Ïµkğ³k=ğ±kTğšª+ğ›ˆkT,\begin{equation}\label{eq: double-security-pred.framework} \left\{\begin{array}{lll}  y_k &= \boldsymbol{x}_k^{\text{T}} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{\boldsymbol{x}} + \epsilon_k\\ \boldsymbol{z}_k &= \boldsymbol{x}_k^{\text{T}}\boldsymbol{\Gamma}+ \boldsymbol{\eta}_k^{\text{T}},\\ \end{array} \right. \end{equation} ğšª\boldsymbol{\Gamma} usually full-rank (necessarily), ğ›ƒğ±\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\boldsymbol{x}} coefficients vector E(Ïµk|ğ±j,Ij,Rj)=0,E(ğ›ˆğ¤|ğ±j,Ij,Rj)=0.\begin{equation} E{\left(\epsilon_k|\boldsymbol{x}_j,I_j,R_j\right)} = 0, \;\; E{\left(\boldsymbol{\eta_k}|\boldsymbol{x}_j,I_j,R_j\right)} = 0. \end{equation} proposal () property form : (ykâˆ’ğ³kTğ›ƒğ³)|ğ±k=(Ïµâˆ’ğ›ˆkTğšªâˆ’1ğ›ƒğ±)|ğ±k,\begin{equation}\label{eq: property 2-sec prediction} \left(y_k - \boldsymbol{z}_k^{\text{T}}\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\boldsymbol{z}}\right)|\boldsymbol{x}_k = \left(\epsilon - \boldsymbol{\eta}_k^{\text{T}}\boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{-1}\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\right)|\boldsymbol{x}_k, \end{equation} Î²ğ³=Î“âˆ’1Î²ğ±.\begin{equation*} \beta_{\boldsymbol{z}} = \Gamma^{-1}\beta_{\boldsymbol{x}}. \end{equation*}

what: When there are more calibration than response-model variables
title: Theory for missing not at random non-response correction
text: First, lets consider ğ›ğ³*\boldsymbol{b}_{\boldsymbol{z}}^{*}, asymptotic limit : ğ›ğ³=(âˆ‘kâˆˆSdkRkFâ€²k(ğ±kTğ›Œ)ğ±kğ³kT)âˆ’1Ã—âˆ‘kâˆˆSdkRkFâ€²k(ğ±kTğ›Œ)ğ±kyk,\begin{equation}\label{eq: b_z}     \boldsymbol{b}_{\boldsymbol{z}} =  \left(\sum_{k \S}{d_kR_kF'_k(\boldsymbol{x}_k^{\text{T}}\boldsymbol{\lambda})\boldsymbol{x}_k}\boldsymbol{z}_k^{\text{T}}\right)^{-1} \times \sum_{k \S}{d_kR_kF'_k(\boldsymbol{x}_k^{\text{T}}\boldsymbol{\lambda})\boldsymbol{x}_ky_k}, \end{equation} , alongside ğ›ğ³\boldsymbol{b}_{\boldsymbol{z}}, said exist apart result prediction. prediction model fails, got ğ›ğ³âˆ’ğ›ƒğ³\boldsymbol{b}_{\boldsymbol{z}} - \boldsymbol{\beta}_{\boldsymbol{z}} long ğ›Œ\boldsymbol{\lambda} converged finite ğ›Œ*\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{*}. Chang Kott (2008) considered case extended weighting approach replacing reformulated calibration equation (): ğ¬=1N[âˆ‘kâˆˆSdkRkFk(ğ±kTğ›Œ)ğ³kğ±kâˆ’âˆ‘kâˆˆSdkğ±k]=ğŸ\begin{equation}\label{eq: reformulated calib. eq.} \boldsymbol{s} = \frac{1}{N} \left[\sum_{k \S}{d_kR_kF_k(\boldsymbol{x}_k^{\text{T}}\boldsymbol{\lambda})\boldsymbol{z}_k}\boldsymbol{x}_k- \sum_{k \S}{d_k\boldsymbol{x}_k}\right] = \boldsymbol{0} \end{equation} finding ğ›Œ\boldsymbol{\lambda} minimizes ğ¬Tğğ¬\boldsymbol{s}^{\text{T}}\boldsymbol{Q}\boldsymbol{s} symmetric positive ğ\boldsymbol{Q}. various ways pick ğ\boldsymbol{Q} well dealing ğšª\boldsymbol{\Gamma} full rank. Couple examples might found Kott Liao (2017). example, one options use ğâˆ’1=DIAG[(Nâˆ’1âˆ‘Sdkğ±k)(Nâˆ’1âˆ‘Sdkğ±kâŠ¤)]\displaystyle \mathbf{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{-1} = \text{DIAG}\left[\left({N}^{-1} \sum_{S} d_k \mathbf{\boldsymbol{x}}_k\right) \left({N}^{-1}\sum_{S} d_k \mathbf{\boldsymbol{x}}_k^\top \right)\right]. finding ğ›Œ\boldsymbol{\lambda}, dimension ğ±kT\boldsymbol{x}_k^{\text{T}} reduced way: ğ±ÌƒkT=Nâˆ’1ğâˆ‘jâˆˆSdjRjFkâ€²(ğ³jTğ›Œ)ğ±jğ³jT=ğ±kT(âˆ‘jâˆˆSdjRjFkâ€²(ğ³jTğ›Œ)ğ±jğ±jT)âˆ’1âˆ‘jâˆˆSdjRjFkâ€²(ğ³jTğ )ğ±jğ³jT=ğ±kTğğ³.\begin{align*} \tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}_k^T &= N^{-1} \boldsymbol{Q}\sum_{j \S} d_j R_j F_k' \left( \boldsymbol{z}_j^T \boldsymbol{\lambda}\right) \boldsymbol{x}_j \boldsymbol{z}_j^T\\ &= \boldsymbol{x}_k^T \left( \sum_{j \S} d_j R_j F_k' \left( \boldsymbol{z}_j^T \boldsymbol{\lambda}\right) \boldsymbol{x}_j \boldsymbol{x}_j^T \right)^{-1} \sum_{j \S} d_j R_j F_k' \left( \boldsymbol{z}_j^T \mathbf{g} \right) \boldsymbol{x}_j \boldsymbol{z}_j^T\\ &= \boldsymbol{x}_k^T \mathbf{B}_{\boldsymbol{z}}. \end{align*} Another approach component reduction, proposed Andridge Little (2011), works without searching ğ›Œ\boldsymbol{\lambda} even rely picking ğ\boldsymbol{Q} matrix- idea relies satisfying âˆ‘kâˆˆSwkğ±Ìƒk=âˆ‘kâˆˆSdkRkFkğ±Ìƒk=âˆ‘kâˆˆSdkğ±Ìƒk\begin{equation}\label{eq: reformulated calib.eq} \sum_{k \S} w_k \tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}_k = \sum_{k \S} d_k R_k F_k \tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}_k = \sum_{k \S} d_k \tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}_k \end{equation} setting ğ±ÌƒkT=ğ±kTğ€T,\begin{equation}\label{eq: setting &L} \tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}_k^{\text{T}} = \boldsymbol{x}_k^{\text{T}}\boldsymbol{}^{\text{T}}, \end{equation} ğ€T=(âˆ‘SRjğ±jğ±jT)âˆ’1âˆ‘SRjğ±jğ³jT\boldsymbol{}^{\text{T}} =\left(\sum_{S}{R_j\boldsymbol{x}_j\boldsymbol{x}_j^{\text{T}}}\right)^{-1} \sum_{S}{R_j\boldsymbol{x}_j\boldsymbol{z}_j^{\text{T}}}. , reduction dimensions needed obtained ğ±Ìƒk\tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}_k one able perform generalized calibration weighting technique. far, method implemented part MNAR:gencal() function.

title: Generalized calibration function based on sampling::gencalib â€” gencal
text: Xs matrix calibration variables Zs matrix instrumental variables d vector initial weights, derived sampling design method method upon sampling::gencalib() function called eps describes desired accuracy level convergence-related maxit maximum number iterations sampling::gencalib() since works iteratively tol desired tolerance totals vector population totals (including totals Xs Zs)

title: Generalized calibration function based on sampling::gencalib â€” gencal
text: Andridge, Rebecca R, Roderick JA Little. 2011. â€œProxy Pattern-Mixture Analysis Survey Nonresponse.â€ Journal Official Statistics 27 (2): 153. Chang, T., P. S. Kott. 2008. â€œUsing Calibration Weighting Adjust Nonresponse Plausible Model.â€ Biometrika 95 (3): 555â€“71. https://doi.org/10.1093/biomet/asn022. Deville, Jean-Claude, Carl-Erik SÃ¤rndal. 1992. â€œCalibration Estimators Survey Sampling.â€ Journal American Statistical Association 87 (418): 376â€“82. Estevao, Victor, Carl SÃ¤rndal. n.d. â€œFunctional Form Approach Calibration.â€ Journal Â®cial Statistics 16 (4): 379Â±399. https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/functional-form-approach-calibration/docview/1266846662/se-2. Isaki, C. T., W. . Fuller. 1982. â€œSurvey Design Regression Super-Population Model.â€ Journal American Statistical Association 77 (377): 89â€“96. Kott, Phillip S., Ted Chang. 2010. â€œUsing Calibration Weighting Adjust Nonignorable Unit Nonresponse.â€ Journal American Statistical Association 105 (491): 1265â€“75. https://doi.org/10.1198/jasa.2010.tm09016. Kott, Phillip S., Dan Liao. 2017. â€œCalibration Weighting Nonresponse Missing Random: Allowing Calibration Response-Model Variables.â€ Journal Survey Statistics Methodology 5 (2): 159â€“74. https://doi.org/10.1093/jssam/smx003.

title: Generalized calibration function based on sampling::gencalib â€” gencal
text: Maciej Ostapiuk Maciej BerÄ™sewicz based Kott Chang (2010) Kott Liao (2017)

title: Generalized calibration function based on sampling::gencalib â€” gencal
code: ## Generate the data to formulate response model, calibration variables and target variable  set.seed(123) n <- 10000 x1 <- rlnorm(n, 0, 1) x2 <- rexp(n, 1) x3 <-  rpois(n,2) y <- 1 + x1 + x2 + rnorm(n) pr <- plogis(1 + 0.5*x1 - 0.5*y) pop_data <- data.frame(x1, x2, y, pr) totals <- c(N = n, colSums(pop_data[, c("x1", "x2", "y")])) flag <- rbinom(n, 1, pop_data$pr) sample <- pop_data[flag == 1, ] sample$d <- n/nrow(sample)  ## case when dim(Xs) == dim(Zs) g <- gencal(Xs = stats::model.matrix(~ x1 + x2, data = sample),             Zs = stats::model.matrix(~ x1 + y, data = sample),             d = sample$d,             pop_totals = totals,             method = "raking",             eps = .Machine$double.eps,             maxit = 100,             tol = 1e-8)  head(g) #display only couple of first output values #> [1] 1.1800080 2.6205677 1.0000360 1.1813942 0.6259329 0.7588780    ## case when dim(Xs) > dim(Zs) g1 <-gencal(Xs = stats::model.matrix(~ x1 + x2, data = sample),             Zs = stats::model.matrix(~ y, data = sample),             d = sample$d,             pop_totals = totals,             method = "raking",             eps = .Machine$double.eps,             maxit = 100,             tol = 1e-8)  head(g1) #display only couple of first output values #> [1] 0.9848552 1.3473675 0.9738708 1.0238946 0.8732709 0.9509450

title: The main function for the not missing at random non-response â€” mnar

title: The main function for the not missing at random non-response â€” mnar
text: Returns list containing: g â€“ g-weight sums sample size, Xs â€“ matrix used calibration (.e. Intercept, X X_q transformed calibration quantiles), totals â€“ vector totals (.e. N, pop_totals pop_quantiles), method â€“ selected method, backend â€“ selected backend.

title: The main function for the not missing at random non-response â€” mnar
text: Maciej Ostapiuk, Maciej BerÄ™sewicz

title: The main function for the not missing at random non-response â€” mnar
code: # Set seed for reproducibility set.seed(123)  # Define sample size n <- 10000  # Generate variables x1 <- rlnorm(n, 0, 1) x2 <- rexp(n, 1) x3 <-  rpois(n,2) y <- 1 + x1 + x2 + rnorm(n)  # Calculate probabilities pr <- plogis(1 + 0.5*x1 - 0.5*y)  # Create population data frame pop_data <- data.frame(x1, x2, y, pr)  # Calculate population totals totals <- c(N = n, colSums(pop_data[, c("x1", "x2", "y")]))  # Generate flag variable based on probabilities flag <- rbinom(n, 1, pop_data$pr)  # Create sample based on flag sample <- pop_data[flag == 1, ] sample$d <- n/nrow(sample)   # Case when dim(response) == dim(calibration) g <- mnar(response = ~ x1 + y,             calibration =  ~ x1 + x2,             data = sample, dweights = sample$d,             pop_totals = totals,             method = "gencalib")  head(g) #display only couple of first output values #> [1] 1.1800080 2.6205677 1.0000360 1.1813942 0.6259329 0.7588780  ## Case when dim(response) < dim(calibration) g1 <- mnar(response = ~ y,              calibration =  ~ x1 + x2,              data = sample, dweights = sample$d,              pop_totals = totals,              method = "gencalib")  head(g1) #display only couple of first output values #> [1] 0.9848552 1.3473675 0.9738708 1.0238946 0.8732709 0.9509450
